player.name: Vincent Kompany
player.description:
In the summer of 2008, at the age of 22, Vincent signed from Hamburg and joined Barclays Premier League side Manchester City for approximately £6 million.
At the end of 2010/11, then team manager Roberto Mancini praised Kompany's "incredible" season and claimed that with his attitude and mentality, Kompany can become one of the best defenders in Europe.
Kompany was included in the Barclays Premier League Team of the Year two years in a row in 2011 and 2012 and won the Premier League Player of the season in 2012.

statistic.bodyCopy: Barclays Premier League Player of the season
Manchester City Players Player of the Year

data.key: Manchester City Players Player of the Year
Barclays Premier League Player of the season

player.name: Shuan Goater
player.description:
Having scored 103 goals in 189 games, Shaun Goater became an iconic figure over the course of his five-year association with the Club and can be considered one of greatest goalscorers to ever wear the sky blue shirt.
Some 13 years later, Shaun is also arguably one of the club’s most influential players in recent history, thanks to his goals which helped to fire City back into the big time after years spent in the abyss.
These qualities and his commitment to raising footballing standards across the board in his home country earned Shaun an MBE for services to sport and young people in 2003. Therefore, it’s no surprise that this popularity extends to his homeland, too - Bermuda’s most famous son was toasted with the first "Shaun Goater Day" after he was awarded the freedom of the island on 21 June 2000.
“Feed the Goat and he will score…” was his chant, still heard from time-to-time in the Etihad Stadium.

statistic.bodyCopy: Football League Second Division play-offs winner
Football League First Division Top Scorer

data.key: Football League Second Division play-offs winner
Football League First Division To p Scorer, 2001/02

player.name: Uwe Rosler
player.description:
In March 1994, Rösler joined Manchester City on trial and within the first 12 games the move was made permanent, with reports of the transfer fee varying between £375,000 and £500,000.
In the 94’ FA cup match against Notts County Uwe scored four goals, becoming the first Manchester City player to score four in an FA Cup tie since Johnny Hart in 1953. His performances that season meant he was the Club's leading goalscorer, and went on to win the Club's Player of the Year award.

statistic.bodyCopy: Entered into the Manchester City Hall of Fame

data.key: Entered into the Manchester City Hall of Fame in 2009

player.name: David Silva
player.description:
On 30th June 2010, Manchester City announced that they had reached an agreement with Valencia over the transfer of Silva and that he would join the Club on a four-year deal.
Silva began the 2011/12 season in fine form, scoring the third goal in City's 4–0 thrashing of Swansea City and was voted man of the match. On 17th September 2012, Silva signed a new five-year deal at Manchester City, committing himself to the Etihad Stadium until 2017. He finished the 12/13’ season with four goals and ten assists in 32 League appearances for City.

statistic.bodyCopy: Manchester City Player of the Month awards
PFA Premier League Team of the Year

data.key: PFA Premier League Team of the Year
4 Manchester City Player of the Month awards

player.name: Joe Hart
player.description:
Hart was signed from Shrewsbury Town by Stuart Pearce in 2006 and went to Blackpool, Tranmere Rovers and Birmingham City on loan. He returned to City after the FIFA World Cup in South Africa, 2010.
Hart won the BPL Golden Glove award for the second year running in 2011/12 and helped City win their first Barclays Premier League title and their first top-flight title for 44 years, which they clinched on that famous final day of the season by beating Queens Park Rangers 3–2.

statistic.bodyCopy: time winner of the BPL Golden Glove award in 10/11, 11/12, 12/13

item.description: Originally the City of Manchester stadium, the ground was developed for the 2002 Commonwealth Games. In 2011 the name of the stadium was changed to the Etihad Stadium, now most commonly called ‘The Etihad.’ Like many other football grounds, ‘The Etihad’ has held many different sporting and entertainment events. Since the Commonwealth Games the stadium has hosted the 2008 UEFA Cup Final, England football internationals, rugby league matches, boxing world title fights and live music concerts.

statistics.description:
Capacity: 47,805

Field Dimensions: 105m x 68m

Surface: Desso GrassMaster.
